original_data.question: A male newborn born at 27 weeks' gestation is evaluated for rapid breathing and hypoxia shortly after birth. His mother had no prenatal care. Cardiopulmonary examination shows normal heart sounds, intercostal retractions, and nasal flaring. An x-ray of the chest shows low lung volumes, air bronchograms, and diffuse ground-glass opacities. He is started on nasal continuous positive airway pressure. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

options.A: Bilateral pleural effusions on lung ultrasound
options.B: Corkscrew-shaped organisms on umbilical cord culture
options.C: Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy

model_response:
This patient has respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is the most common cause of respiratory failure in premature infants. RDS is caused by a deficiency of surfactant, which is produced by type II alveolar cells. Surfactant deficiency leads to an increase in alveolar surface tension, and collapse of the alveoli. On x-ray, this appears as a diffuse reticulogranular pattern, with ground-glass opacities. The initial treatment for RDS is to provide mechanical ventilation with a goal of maintaining PaO2 above 60 mm Hg and PaCO2 below 60 mm Hg. Administration of exogenous surfactant is the next step in management, if ventilatory support is required for more than 6 hours. Bilateral pleural effusions can be seen in RDS, but are less common in the absence of patent ductus aeriosus. Corkscrew-shaped organisms on umbilical cord culture would suggest the diagnosis of Candida albicans, which can cause respiratory distress in premature infants. Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli are seen in RDS, but are not specific for this condition. Meconium-stained fluid on deep suctioning suggests the presence of meconium aspiration syndrome, which is not related to RDS.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
An infant during the first 28 days after birth.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Taking ambient air into the lungs; breathing in.
Sub-optimal OXYGEN levels in the ambient air of living organisms.
The process of giving birth to one or more offspring.
Care provided the pregnant woman in order to prevent complications, and decrease the incidence of maternal and prenatal mortality.
Pertaining to both the heart and the lungs.
The marked inward movement of the muscles between the ribs during inhalation, indicating that there is reduced pressure in the thoracic cavity, and which can be a sign of breathing difficulties.
Enlargement of the nostrils during breathing; although there are many possible causes, it can be a sign of respiratory distress in young infants.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.

An air bronchogram is a pattern of air-filled (low-attenuation) bronchi on a background of opaque (high-attenuation) airless lung. The sign implies (a) patency of proximal airways and (b) evacuation of alveolar air by means of absorption (atelectasis) or replacement (eg, pneumonia) or a combination of these processes. In rare cases, the displacement of air is the result of marked interstitial expansion (eg, lymphoma). [PMID:18195376]
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
